title: Common buttons
description: Buttons help people initiate actions, from sending an email, to sharing a document, to liking a post.

contentChunks.htmlValue: There are five types of common buttons: elevated, filled, filled tonal, outlined, and text.

contentChunks.footer:
1. Elevated button
2. Filled button
3. Filled tonal button
4. Outlined button
5. Text button
contentChunks.altText: The 5 types of common buttons

contentChunks.htmlValue: Resources

TypeResourceStatus
DesignDesign kit (Figma)Available
M2 guideline – ButtonsAvailable
ImplementationMDC- AndroidAvailable
Jetpack ComposeAvailable
FlutterAvailable
WebAvailable
Takeaways

• Choose the type of button based on the importance of the action. The more important the action is, the more emphasis its button should have.
  • All buttons have fully rounded corners
  • There are four common color mappings for buttons, each with a light and dark theme
What's new

• Color: New color mappings and compatibility with dynamic color. Icons and labels now share the same color.
  • Icons: Standard size for leading and trailing icons is now 18dp
  • Shape: Fully rounded corner radius, taller height, and new minimum width
  • Typography: Button text is in sentence case, no ALL CAPS
  • Types: Three new button types – elevated button, filled button, and filled tonal button – replace what was previously known as contained button.

contentChunks.footer: Buttons now have fully rounded corners
contentChunks.altText: Diagram noting rounded corner radius of button container

contentChunks.footer: M2: Buttons have a height of 36dp and slightly rounded corner radius. Button labels use ALL CAPS.
contentChunks.altText: Rectangular M2 buttons

contentChunks.footer: M3: Buttons are taller at 40dp and have fully rounded corners. Button labels use sentence case.
contentChunks.altText: Round-cornered M3 buttons

contentChunks.htmlValue:

contentChunks.footer: Elevated, filled, filled tonal, outlined, and text buttons
contentChunks.altText: 5 types of buttons

contentChunks.htmlValue: Usage

Buttons communicate actions that users can take. They are typically placed throughout your UI, in places like:

  • Dialogs
  • Modal windows
  • Forms
  • Cards
  • Toolbars

contentChunks.footer: Example video-calling screen with 2 buttons

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Buttons are just one option for representing actions in a product and shouldn’t be overused. Too many buttons on a screen disrupts the visual hierarchy.

Consider placing additional actions in a navigation drawer, set of chips, text links, or icon buttons.

contentChunks.footer: Use buttons for discrete actions.
contentChunks.altText: 1 button placed on bottom right of screen

contentChunks.footer: Don’t clutter your UI with too many buttons. Consider presenting lower-priority actions in overflow menus or as icon buttons.
contentChunks.altText: 3 buttons set side by side on bottom of screen

contentChunks.footer: A button container’s width is dynamically set to fit its label text.
contentChunks.altText: Filled button on menu screen

contentChunks.footer: A button container’s width shouldn’t be narrower than its label text.
contentChunks.altText: Filled button with label text overflowing the container

contentChunks.footer: Button container width can be set according to the responsive layout grid.
contentChunks.altText: Wide filled button
5 types of buttons

contentChunks.htmlValue:
There are 5 types of buttons:

  1. Elevated button
  2. Filled button
  3. Filled tonal button
  4. Outlined button
  5. Text button
Anatomy

contentChunks.footer:
1. Label text
2. Container
3. Icon (optional)
contentChunks.altText: Anatomy diagram numbering 3 elements of buttons

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Label text

Label text is the most important element of a button. It describes the action that will occur if a user taps a button.

Capitalize the first letter of the first word and proper nouns in button label text. This allows the text to distinguish proper nouns, for example: Book with Flights vs BOOK WITH FLIGHTS.

contentChunks.footer: Use sentence case for button label text, capitalizing the first word and proper nouns.
contentChunks.altText: Button with label text “See all”

contentChunks.footer: Don’t wrap text. For maximum legibility, label text should remain on a single line.
contentChunks.altText: Button with label text “See all recipes”

contentChunks.htmlValue: Text buttons depend on the color and style of label text to be recognizable from other text and elements.

contentChunks.footer: In text buttons, label text should use a different color, style, or layout from other text. In the example above, the Reserve action would be more prominent in a filled button instead of a text button.
contentChunks.altText: Text button labeled "Reserve" in a contrasting green color

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Container

Button containers hold the label text and optional icon. Text buttons have a visible container only when hovered, focused, or pressed.

Button containers have fully rounded corners.

contentChunks.footer: Button containers have fully rounded corners.
contentChunks.altText: Close-up of button container edge

contentChunks.footer: A button’s width can be dynamically set to contain the label text.
contentChunks.altText: Button with the label text “View playlist” within the container

contentChunks.footer: A button’s width shouldn’t be smaller than the button’s label text.
contentChunks.altText: Button with the label text “View playlist” overflowing the container

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Icon (optional)

Icons visually communicate the button’s action and help draw attention. They should be placed on the leading side of the button, before the label text.

contentChunks.footer: Place the icon to the left of the label in buttons with text in left-to-right languages.
contentChunks.altText: Send icon aligned to the left of the button

contentChunks.footer: Place the icon to the right of the label in buttons with text in right-to-left languages.
contentChunks.altText: Send icon aligned to the left of the button

contentChunks.footer: Use icons that clearly communicate their meaning.
contentChunks.altText: Button with shopping cart icon and text label “Add to cart”

contentChunks.footer: Don’t vertically align an icon and text in the center of a button.
contentChunks.altText: Button with Plus icon vertically above the text label “Add to watch list”

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use two icons in the same button.
contentChunks.altText: Button with leading download icon, text label “Download” and trailing close icon

contentChunks.htmlValue: Elevated buttons

Elevated buttons are essentially filled tonal buttons with a shadow. To prevent shadow creep, only use them when absolutely necessary, such as when the button requires visual separation from a patterned background.

contentChunks.footer: Elevated buttons provide separation from a patterned background
contentChunks.altText: Elevated button set on a darker background image of bread loaves

contentChunks.htmlValue: Buttons at higher elevations typically appear more prominent in a design.

contentChunks.footer: Higher elevation increases the prominence of a button.
contentChunks.altText: Elevated button in a restaurant app labeled “Place order”

contentChunks.htmlValue: Filled buttons
Filled buttons have the most visual impact after the FAB, and should be used for important, final actions that complete a flow, like Save, Join now, or Confirm.

contentChunks.footer: Filled buttons have high visual impact when used for important actions.
contentChunks.altText: Video calling app with 2 filled buttons labeled “Join now” and “Present”

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Filled buttons display a container around a text label. Container size can be described in different ways:

  • Set container width to the size of the text label with consistent padding on the left and right
  • Set the container’s relative position to the responsive layout grid

Filled buttons should have containers with a solid color.

contentChunks.footer: Filled button width can be responsive to the layout grid.
contentChunks.altText: Filled button as wide as the mobile screen

contentChunks.htmlValue: Filled tonal buttons

A filled tonal button is an alternative middle ground between filled and outlined buttons. They’re useful in contexts where a lower-priority button requires slightly more emphasis than an outline would give, such as "Next" in an onboarding flow. Tonal buttons use the secondary color mapping.

contentChunks.footer: Filled tonal buttons have less emphasis than other filled buttons.
contentChunks.altText: Shopping app with two tonal-style filled buttons

contentChunks.htmlValue: Outlined buttons

Outlined buttons are medium-emphasis buttons. They contain actions that are important, but aren’t the primary action in an app.

Outlined buttons pair well with filled buttons to indicate an alternative, secondary action.

contentChunks.footer: Outline buttons contain less important supporting actions.
contentChunks.altText: Example screen with a supporting outlined button on the lower left and more important tonal-style filled button on the lower right

contentChunks.htmlValue: Outlined buttons display a stroke around the button container, and by default have no fill.

contentChunks.footer: Outlined buttons display a stroke around the button container.
contentChunks.altText: outlined button as wide as the mobile screen

contentChunks.htmlValue: Outlined buttons can be placed on a variety of backgrounds.

contentChunks.footer: Outlined buttons can be used on backgrounds with a color gradient.
contentChunks.altText: Outlined button labeled RSVP on a blue/green background

contentChunks.footer: Use caution when placing outlined buttons on top of images. Customizing the button to have a contrasting container fill can help ensure legibility of label text. Or, use a filled button instead.
contentChunks.altText: 2 outlined buttons both labeled View Album on photo backgrounds

contentChunks.htmlValue: Text buttons

Text buttons are used for the lowest priority actions, especially when presenting multiple options.

Text buttons can be placed on a variety of backgrounds. Until the button is interacted with, its container isn’t visible.

contentChunks.footer: Use text buttons for the lowest priority actions.
contentChunks.altText: Example calendar screen with 3 text buttons

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Text buttons are often embedded in components like cards, dialogs, and snackbars. Because text buttons don’t have a visible container in their default state, they don’t distract from nearby content.

The color and style of the label text must always be recognizable from non-button text and elements.

contentChunks.footer: Text button in a snackbar.
contentChunks.altText: Text button labeled “Retry” in a snackbar

contentChunks.footer: Text button against an image background.
contentChunks.altText: Text button labeled “View album” on an album cover background

contentChunks.htmlValue: In cards, text buttons help maintain an emphasis on card content.

contentChunks.footer: Text button in a card.
contentChunks.altText: Text button labeled “Learn more” in an information card about sourdough bread

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Dialogs use text buttons because the absence of a container helps unify the action with the dialog text.

Align text buttons to the ending edge of dialogs, on the right for left-to-right languages and on the left for right-to-left languages.

contentChunks.footer: Text buttons in a dialog.
contentChunks.altText: 2 text buttons labeled “Cancel” and “Subscribe” aligned to the lower right side of a dialog

contentChunks.htmlValue: Responsive layout
When scaling layouts for large screen devices, buttons can adapt their visual presentation, alignment, and arrangement to fit different contexts and user needs.

contentChunks.footer: Filled buttons in this flights app are left-aligned beside flight information on desktop screens.
contentChunks.altText: Flights app on desktop device with buttons to the left of flight information

contentChunks.footer: Filled buttons in this flights app are right-aligned below flight information on mobile screens.
contentChunks.altText: Flights app on mobile device with buttons below flight information

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Buttons scale with their parent container

Buttons are typically placed in containers such as cards or dialogs. As a parent container scales to adapt to different screen sizes, a button’s width, position, and alignment within the container can also change.

contentChunks.footer: A button’s position and size scales in relationship to its container.
contentChunks.altText: Example of button width expanding with screen width

contentChunks.htmlValue: Buttons can be aligned left, right, or center as the parent container scales.

contentChunks.footer: A button’s position and size scales in relationship to its container.
contentChunks.altText: Example of button width expanding with screen width

contentChunks.htmlValue: Define the position and alignment of button elements such as text and icons in relationship to their container. For example, the icon and label text within a button remain centered and anchored to each other as the button width scales.

contentChunks.footer: Group internal elements so that they scale together. Icons and label text remain centered when button width increases.
contentChunks.altText: 2 buttons with horizontally centered text labels

contentChunks.footer: Don’t ungroup elements inside of a button container. This can lead to unwanted movement, such as the icon and label text anchoring to opposite sides of the button.
contentChunks.altText: 1 button with centered text label, 1 button with icon and label aligned to opposite edges

contentChunks.htmlValue: The size and placement of buttons can change as parent containers, such as cards, adapt for larger screens.

contentChunks.altText: Two buttons scaling to accommodate different device sizes

contentChunks.htmlValue: Use cases

Users should be able to:

  • Use a button to perform an action
  • Navigate to and activate a button with assistive tech
Interaction & style
Similarly styled components shouldn’t be used together if they don’t each pass the 3:1 contrast ratio. Higher contrast helps differentiate between a group of similar components.

contentChunks.footer: Higher contrast helps differentiate elements.
Don't use buttons together if they don't each pass the 3:1 contrast ratio.
It's fine to use a single button that does not pass the 3:1 contrast ration since it's not in a group.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Keyboard navigation

KeysActions
TabFocus lands on (non-disabled) button
Space / EnterActivates the (non-disabled) button
Labeling elements

The accessibility label for a button ideally comes from the visible label text on the button such as Done, Send, or Reply. Consider aligning the accessibility label (used for assistive technology devices like screen readers) with the visible label text.

If the button doesn’t have visible label text, which is the case for icon buttons, have the accessibility label describe the action that the button is executing, such as Favorite, Bookmark, or Send message.

Resources

  • Information on clustering
